#Text=Grozny
#Text=Grozny ( Russian : Гро́зный GROHZ-nyh ) is the capital city of Chechnya .

#Text=Since 2009 — the end of the Second Chechen War — Grozny has undergone a renaissance in development and many abandoned or low-quality apartments and houses demolished and replaced with newer re-built apartment buildings and suburbs .
#Text=Grozny was built as a Russian fort .
#Text=Throughout 1994 and the early 2000s the city underwent chaos as Russian military battled Chechen rebels .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Grozny was founded in 1818 as a Russian fort .
#Text=It was a major stronghold for the Russians during the Caucasian Wars during 1818-1864 .
#Text=During the early 20th century , population boomed because of the city 's rich oil reserves which drove many Russians from other parts of the country to work in the city .
#Text=During World War II , Josef Stalin accused the Chechen people as a whole with working with the Nazis to overthrow the Soviet government .
#Text=The Chechens were labeled as a " traitor people " .
#Text=It was decided to deport all Chechens and Ingushis from the then Chechen-Ingush Autonomous Republic into exile in Central Asia .

#Text=The republic was abolished and re-peopled with settlers from other parts of the Soviet Union : neighbouring North Ossetia , South Ossetia and Dagestan , Central Russia , Georgia and the Ukraine .

#Text=When many of the harsher Stalin 's policies were condemned and rolled back by the new Soviet leadership after 1956 , the Chechen-Inglush Autonomous Republic was reinstated and Chechens were allowed to return to their homeland , doubling its population .

#Text=However , no provisions were made to return the non-Chechen newcomers to their original places of residence or to compensate returning Chechens for homes and property that they have lost , much of it now in hands of the newcomers .
#Text=This and the experience of deportation caused bitter resentment between Chechen and non-Chechen population of the Republic .

#Text=Many Chechens with no means to subsist in the countryside anymore settled in Grozny , which has been an industrial city with predominantly Russian population even before the deportation , having only a handful of Chechen residents up until then .
#Text=In the 1990s , rebels began to form groups in an attempt to destroy Russian control in the city and the rest of Chechnya .
#Text=The government lost partial control and the city was dangerous .
#Text=Peace began to return during the late stages of the war in the 2000s , and the government is beginning to reconstruct the city .
#Text=Get in
#Text=Because Grozny was devastated by years of war , transportation is often tricky and hard as much of Grozny 's transportation system has been destroyed .
#Text=However , since reconstruction began , it 's possible to take a flight to the city or use a train , bus or the convenient highway system .
#Text=By plane
#Text=For Sep 2016 there were only three main gateways to Grozny by air : the Vnukovo and Domodedovo Airports in Moscow and Bishkek Airport in Kyrgyzstan .
#Text=Grozny Airport ( GRV ) .
#Text=By train
#Text=A night train departs from Moscow every second day , taking two nights .
#Text=Due to terrorist threats , this train is heavily guarded , expect delays and hassles .
#Text=Also , there is a night train from Rostov-on-the-Don and a day train from Astrakhan .
#Text=Local trains connect with Khasavyurt and Gudermes .
#Text=By car
#Text=Grozny is connected to the rest of Russia by a large highway system .
#Text=The P-308 , P-307 and M-29 highways connect the city to other cities in Russia .
#Text=Keep in mind that it 's best to take a map with you , or else you can get lost .
#Text=By bus
#Text=A bus usually leaves from Nazran to Grozny and other cities in the Caucasus region of Russia , so remember when you are going to stop .
#Text=Get around
#Text=It 's very difficult to get around Grozny since during the Siege of Grozny the tram and trolley system was almost destroyed .
#Text=The tram is not expected to re-open , but the trolley has re-opened .
#Text=The trolley still has not fully developed , so it 's best to use a car in the city .
#Text=There is a ( religious ) taxi company operating in the city called Islam , which uses green-painted cars .
#Text=See
#Text=Akhmad Kadyrov Mosque .
#Text=Completed in 2008 and locally known as the Heart of Chechnya , this is by far the largest mosque in Russia and one of the more lavish in the world .
#Text=Church of St. Michael the Archangel ' .
#Text=Renovated after being almost destroyed during the Siege of Grozny .
#Text=Another good place to go is to Downtown Grozny which features many lights and shops and restaurants that are at good prices .
#Text=There are also many stands which sell fruit and beer .
#Text=Do
#Text=On weekends , you can go and watch some football ( soccer ) at the Sultan Bilimkhanov Stadium .
#Text=FC Terek Grozny plays there in the Russian Premier League .
#Text=Buy
#Text=Because of the regional war 's effect on the economy , many items in Grozny are cheap .
#Text=Do n't expect to find many Western essentials you can find in stores of other parts of the country .
#Text=Many authentic swords and daggers can be bought at low prices .
#Text=There is a flea market with many Chechen and Russian merchants .
#Text=Again , do n't expect much and expect to find some bootleg copies of well-known products .
#Text=Eat
#Text=Café Oasis is a reasonable place to eat in downtown Grozny .
#Text=It will be difficult to find though .
#Text=You might want to bring a guide .
#Text=Drink
#Text=There are n't many bars in the city , but there are many local vendors which sell beer .
#Text=Beer can only be sold legally between 08:00 and 10:00 .
#Text=Sleep
#Text=A good and cheap hotel is the Hotel Arena City .
#Text=The hotel is new and modern , and has many essentials you can find in other hotels in the rest of the country .
#Text=Many other hotels are being built .
#Text=It is reported that rebels closely monitor hotels , so be careful .
#Text=Hotel Grozny City , pr .
#Text=Kadyrova 1/16 , ☏ +78712 29-60-00 , ✉ info@groznycityhotel.ru .
#Text=Stay safe
#Text=Grozny has only partly stabilized enough to be safe for travel .
#Text=Take extreme caution when visiting war-torn areas as there are some unexploded land-mines .
#Text=Rebels often take tourists as hostages , so try to blend in with the population .
#Text=It 's advised not to speak Chechen in the city , as a foreigner speaking the language will attract a lot of unwanted attention .
#Text=If you plan to visit Grozny , take lots of precaution .
